JavaScript is a versatile language that can be used for both front-end and back-end development.
Use 'let' and 'const' instead of 'var' to declare variables for better scope management.
Arrow functions provide a shorter syntax for writing function expressions.
Template literals allow for multi-line strings and string interpolation.
Destructuring assignment makes it easy to extract values from arrays or objects.
The spread operator (...) can be used to expand arrays or objects.
Promises are a way to handle asynchronous operations in JavaScript.
Async/await syntax makes working with promises easier and more readable.
JavaScript has first-class functions, meaning functions can be treated like any other variable.
Use '=== ' for strict equality checks to avoid type coercion issues.
The 'map' method creates a new array populated with the results of calling a provided function on every element in the calling array.
The 'filter' method creates a new array with all elements that pass the test implemented by the provided function.
The 'reduce' method executes a reducer function on each element of the array, resulting in a single output value.
JavaScript's 'this' keyword behaves differently in arrow functions compared to regular functions.
Use 'forEach' to execute a function on each element of an array without returning a new array.
The 'setTimeout' function allows you to execute a function after a specified delay.
The 'setInterval' function allows you to execute a function repeatedly at specified intervals.
JavaScript supports object-oriented programming through prototypes and classes.
Use 'try...catch' for error handling in asynchronous code.
The 'fetch' API provides a modern way to make HTTP requests.
JavaScript has a rich set of built-in methods for manipulating arrays and objects.
Use 'localStorage' and 'sessionStorage' for client-side storage of data.
The 'window' object represents the browser's window and provides methods to interact with it.
JavaScript can manipulate the DOM to create dynamic web pages.
Event delegation allows you to manage events more efficiently by using a single event listener.
Use 'addEventListener' to attach events to DOM elements.
The 'DOMContentLoaded' event fires when the initial HTML document has been completely loaded and parsed.
JavaScript supports modules, allowing you to break your code into reusable pieces.
Use 'import' and 'export' to work with modules in JavaScript.
The 'Math' object provides properties and methods for mathematical constants and functions.
